The  project  road  provides  the  only  substantial  link  between  the  Rasht 
Valley and the capital Dushanbe, and comprises part of an international 
corridor  to  the  Kyrgyz  Republic  and  the  People's  Republic  of  China 
(PRC).  The  Project  will  rehabilitate  140  kilometers  (km)  of  the 
Dushanbe-Nurobod section of the transport corridor linking Tajikistan to 
the Kyrgyz Republic and onward to the PRC, as well as 77 km of rural 
roads serving poor villages.  Tajikistan is the poorest country among the 
Central  Asian  republics,  with  a  poverty  incidence  of  83%.  The  poverty 
incidence in the project area is 91%.  
 
The  Project  will  rehabilitate  a  key  national  and  international  transport 
corridor. The project road provides the primary link between Dushanbe 
and  the  Rasht  Valley,  to  the  northeast.  For  several  months  during  the 
winter,  the  road  also  serves  as  a  link  between  the  northern  Sugdh 
region  and  the  rest  of  Tajikistan.  The  project  area  was  the  scene  of 
heavy  fighting  during  Tajikistan’s  civil  war  in  the  mid-1990s and has a 
poverty  incidence  of  91%.  The  improvement  of  the  rural  roads  will 
improve  access  to  the  main  road  for  poor  villages  not  located  on  the 
main  road,  and  therefore  improve  access  to  regional  markets  and 
Dushanbe.  Numerous  agriculture  and  other  poverty  alleviation  projects 
are  being  implemented  in  the  project  area  by  other  international 
organizations,  and  by  improving  transport  in  the  area  the  Project  will 
enable the full potential of these projects to be realized. The Project will 
facilitate  national  development  and 
regional  cooperation  by 
rehabilitating  the  corridor  connecting  Afghanistan  and  Tajikistan  to  the 
PRC  and  other  countries  in  the  region.  The  Project  will  address  the 
national  problem  of  road  maintenance  by  increasing  financing  for 
maintenance  of  national  roads  and  developing  a  maintenance  system 
for  rural  roads.  The  Project  supports  the  strategy  of  the  Government 
and Asian Development Bank (ADB) to rehabilitate infrastructure and to 
develop international transport corridors. 
 
The objective of the Project is to reduce poverty, by reducing the cost of 
road transport and improving access to markets, and increase regional 
trade  and  cooperation  by  rehabilitating  the  road  linking  Dushanbe  to 
Nurobod  in  the  Rasht  Valley  and  on  to  the  Kyrgyz  Republic  and  PRC. 
The  Project  will  (i)  reduce  transport  costs  on  the  Dushanbe-Kyrgyz 
border  road;  (ii)  provide  agricultural  and  industrial  enterprises  with  all-
weather  access  to  markets  within  the  country,  and eventually abroad; 
(iii) improve access of the rural poor population to market opportunities, 
other economic activities, and social services by improving rural roads;

and (iv) strengthen the Government’s institutional capacities for efficient

Project comprises improvement of about 140 km of the mostly two-lane

the improved road sections.

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

 
A. 
 
2. 
The road subsector is the most important component of domestic transport in Tajikistan. 
The combined length of Tajikistan’s road network is about 26,000 kilometers (km), consisting of 
4,700  km  of  national  roads  and  21,300  km  of  local  roads.  The  scope  of  the  network  is 
considered adequate to accommodate existing traffic levels and support economic growth and 
sustainable development in the medium term. The Ministry of Transport (MOT) has jurisdiction 
over 13,700 km, including all of the national roads and 42% of the local roads (9,000 km). The 
remaining 12,300 km of local roads not under MOT jurisdiction are mostly rural and farm roads. 
The major part of the network was constructed before 1970, and inadequate maintenance and 
damage  from  civil  conflict  and  recent  natural  disasters  have  left  it  in  a  state  of  severe 
deterioration.  Of  the  national  roads,  42%  are  asphalt,  50%  are  other  pavement,  and  8%  are 
gravel. Many of the asphalt roads are in a seriously deteriorated condition, and in many places 
the asphalt has been worn away by years of traffic and lack of maintenance. Of the total roads 
in Tajikistan, 20% are estimated to be in fair condition, 48% in poor condition, and 32% in very 
poor condition. Practically none of the roads is estimated to be in good or very good condition. 
  
3. 
The  breakup  of  the  former  Soviet  Union,  political  and  regional  instability  during  the 
country’s  civil  war,  and  major  natural  disasters  severely  disrupted  economic  activities  and 
customary trade patterns, and resulted in a dramatic decline in transport demand after Tajikistan 
gained its independence in 1991. As Tajikistan’s economy continues to grow, traffic levels are 
expected to increase; however, it is doubtful that the traffic levels of 1990 will be reached within 
the  next  10  years.  There  have  been  major  changes  in  Tajikistan’s  vehicle  fleet  since 
independence.  Despite  the  decrease  in  traffic  levels,  there  has  been  a  trend  of  increasing 
privatization  of  the  road  transport  fleet  and  a  significant  increase  in  automobile  ownership.  Of 
about  180,000  vehicles  registered  in  Tajikistan  in  2001,  cars  comprise  about  70%  and  trucks 
comprise  about  23%.  Only  about  22%  of  vehicles  are  government-owned,  mostly  trucks,  and 
the majority of them are more than 10 years old.

B. 
 
5. 
Tajikistan is the poorest country among the Central Asian republics (CARs), with a per 
capita  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  of  $166  in  2001  and  a  poverty  incidence  of  83%.  The 
summary poverty reduction and social analysis is included in Appendix 3. Average wages are 
less than $1 per day.4 The poverty incidence in the project area is estimated at 91%. The project 
road provides the only substantial link between the Rasht Valley and the capital Dushanbe, and 
comprises part of an international corridor to the Kyrgyz Republic and the People's Republic of 
China  (PRC).  The  Dushanbe-Kyrgyz  border  road  traverses  four  districts  with  approximately 
440,000 inhabitants, mostly living within 20 km of the road. Approximately 140,000 people will 
be directly affected by the Project. Of these inhabitants, the majority live in rural areas where the 
incidence  of  poverty  is  particularly  severe.  The  improvement  of  the  Dushanbe-Kyrgyz  border 
road and selected rural roads will improve access to Dushanbe and other cities in which higher 
prices are paid for agricultural products and there are more job opportunities than in the project 
area.  The  Project  will  lead  to  reduced  transport  costs,  most  of  which  will  be  passed  on  to 
transport  users.  Numerous  agriculture  and  other  poverty  alleviation  projects  are  being 
implemented in the project area by other international organizations, and by improving transport 
in the area the Project will maximize the benefits of these projects.

Maintenance  of  the  road  network  throughout  Tajikistan  virtually  ceased  following  the 
collapse  of  the  Soviet  Union.  Maintenance  funding  was  also  unavailable  during  the  civil  war, 
when numerous bridges and road sections were damaged. Funding for road maintenance has 
decreased  substantially  since  independence,  and  this  inadequate  funding  is  reflected  in  the 
deteriorated condition of the road network. Allocation of funding is often restricted to emergency 
maintenance  needs  and  is  insufficient  for  routine  or  periodic  maintenance  requirements.  It 
appears that little preventative maintenance is currently being undertaken outside of Dushanbe 
as part of a detailed, planned, and scheduled road maintenance program. MOT is responsible 
for planning and coordinating the maintenance of the existing road network in the country. MOT 
conducts  the  maintenance  of  roads  and  bridges  through  five  maintenance  divisions  that  are 
responsible  for  implementing  maintenance  activities  in  their  regions.  These  five  divisions  are 
responsible  for  maintaining  approximately  13,700  km  of  road,  and  employed  3,291  people  in 
2001. The road maintenance divisions are state entities, attached to MOT. 
 
8. 
The  Government’s  Transport  Sector  Policy  Statement  outlines  the  policy  directive 
requiring  development  of  the  transport  sector  to  be  based  on  market-oriented  reforms  and 
restructuring  to  improve  efficiency.  The  Government’s  strategy  for  the  road  subsector  is  to 
rehabilitate  and  maintain  the  road  infrastructure  and  to  develop  an  efficient  road  transport 
industry through an increased role for the private sector in providing transport services, greater 
reliance on cost recovery to finance road maintenance, and rehabilitation of the critical parts of 
the road network and transport services that remain under state control. The Government aims 
to increase expenditures on road maintenance, and has been doing so in line with ADB's policy 
dialogue,  and  to  implement  necessary  changes  to  the  regulatory  framework  to  encourage 
greater involvement by the private sector in road transport. The Government’s strategy includes 
the  development  of  international  road  corridors  to  facilitate  Tajikistan’s  trade  with  other 
countries.

The  Project  will  rehabilitate  a  key  national  and  international  transport  corridor  in 
Tajikistan. The project road provides the primary link between Dushanbe and the Rasht Valley, 
to the northeast. For several months during the winter, the road also serves as a link between 
the northern Sugdh region and the rest of Tajikistan. The project area was the scene of heavy 
fighting during Tajikistan’s civil war in the mid-1990s and has a poverty incidence of 91%. The 
improvement of the rural roads will improve access to the main road for poor villages not located 
on the main road, and therefore improve access to regional markets and Dushanbe. Numerous 
agriculture and other poverty alleviation projects are being implemented in the project area by 
other international organizations, and by improving transport in the area the Project will enable 
the full potential of these projects to be realized. The Project will facilitate national development 
and regional cooperation by rehabilitating the corridor connecting Afghanistan and Tajikistan to 
the PRC and other countries in the region. The project road eventually connects to Sary Tash in 
the Kyrgyz Republic, and to the Osh-Sary Tash-Irkeshtam road corridor currently being studied 
under  ADB's  TA  for  Regional  Cooperation  in  Transport  Projects  in  Central  Asia.10  The  Project 
will address the national problem of road maintenance by increasing financing for maintenance 
of  national  roads  and  developing  a  maintenance  system  for  rural  roads.  The  Project  supports 
the  strategy  of  the  Government  and  ADB  to  rehabilitate  infrastructure  and  to  develop 
international  transport  corridors.  The  second  phase  of  the  rehabilitation  of  the  road  from 
Dushanbe to the Kyrgyz border is included in ADB's Tajikistan program as a firm loan for 2005.

Policy Dialogue and Road Maintenance Financing 

 
23. 
ADB has been intensively involved in policy dialogue for the transport sector in general, 
and  the  road  subsector  in  particular,  since  it  began  its  involvement  with  Tajikistan's  transport 
sector in 1998. Financing of road maintenance is one of the key topics that has been addressed 
in the policy dialogue. As part of the covenants for the Road Rehabilitation Project (footnote 1), 
the  Government  agreed  to  increase  budget  allocations  for  maintenance  and  rehabilitation  of 
roads  under  MOT  administration  by  10%  per  year  plus  inflation  during  2002  to  2004.  The 
Government  has  complied  with  the  required  10%  annual  increase  (plus  inflation)  in  budget 
allocations  for  road  maintenance  and  rehabilitation.13  Allocations  for  road  maintenance  have 
increased  at  an  average  annual  rate  of  29%  since  2001.  The  Government  also  agreed  that 
funding  for  road  maintenance  would  account  for  50%,  60%,  and  65%  of  the  total  budget 
allocation  for  road  maintenance  and  new  construction  in  the  years  2001,  2002,  and  2003, 
respectively.  According  to  budget  data  provided  by  MOT  and  the  Ministry  of  Finance  (MOF), 
budget  allocations  for  road  maintenance  have  accounted  for  57%,  36%,  and  60%  of  the  total 
budget  allocation  for  road  maintenance  and  new  construction  in  2001,  2002,  and  2003, 
respectively.  The  Government  thus  exceeded  the  covenant  in  2001,  fell  substantially  short  in 
2002,  and  failed  to  comply  by  a  small  amount  in  2003.  The  failures  to  comply  are  due  to 
substantial  increases  in  spending  on  construction  of  the  Anzob  Tunnel  (a  national  priority 
project) in 2002 and 2003. The Government requested a modification of the requirement for the 
maintenance financing proportion for 2004 (70%) so that it is consistent with the assurances for 
2005–2007 in the proposed Project (para. 24). ADB approved the request.

allocations  and  actual  expenditures  for  rehabilitation  and  maintenance  (excluding  new

in 2005–2007. Based on the amount allocated for road rehabilitation and maintenance in 2003,

1. 

Traffic Forecast 

 
44. 
Traffic  forecasts  were  prepared  for  the  sections  of  the  project  road  based  on  forecast 
GDP  growth,  population  growth,  and  income  elasticities  of  demand  during  2003–2027 
(Appendix  11).  GDP  is  forecast  to  grow  at  annual  rates  of  5%  through  2012  and  4%  for  the 
remainder  of  the  project  period,  and  population  is  expected  to  increase  at  an  average  annual 
growth rate of 1.6% per year during the project period. Average annual traffic growth rates for 
trucks, buses, and cars are estimated at 6.5%, 4.6% and 6.3%, respectively, during 2003–2012, 
and  4.0%,  3.5%,  and  4.7%  for  the  remainder  of  the  project  period.  In  2027,  total  vehicles  per 
day  are  forecast  to  range  from  19,839  on  the  Dushanbe-Vahdat  section  to  4,922  on  the 
Obigarm-Nurobod section. International generated traffic, arising from increased trade between 
Tajikistan and the PRC, is expected to start in 2010 following completion of other road projects, 
to reach full levels in 2012, and to comprise 61%–72% of total traffic in 2027 except for 14% on 
the  Dushanbe-Vahdat  section.  At  present,  about  50%  of  Tajikistan’s  imports  from  the  PRC 
consist  of  fabric,  chemicals,  cotton, and  tea;  while  cotton  comprises  about  70%  of  Tajikistan’s 
exports  to  the  PRC.  Trade  between  the  two  countries  is  expected  to  increase  following  the 
completion of other road projects and associated cross-border trade agreements. In particular, 
the PRC is expected to provide a large market for Tajikistan’s agricultural output and to become 
a large source of consumer goods for Tajikistan.

Impact on Poverty 

B. 
 
49. 
The  main  causes  of  poverty  in  the  project  area  are  unemployment  and  the  low  prices 
received for agricultural produce. The Project will contribute to poverty alleviation by addressing 
both of these causes (paras. 20–22). The improvement of the Dushanbe-Kyrgyz border road as 
well  as  the  rural  roads  will  improve  access  to  Dushanbe  and  other  locations  in  which  higher 
prices are paid for agricultural products and there are more job opportunities than in the project 
area.  Reductions  in  transport  costs  will  be  passed  on  to  the  users  of  the  transport  services, 
thereby improving the terms of trade for poor farmers in the project area by lowering the costs of 
agricultural  inputs  and  increasing  prices  for  agricultural  outputs.  In  addition,  the  improved 
transport  services  should  increase  the  number  of  traders  traveling  to  the  project  area  to  buy 
produce. Many other income generating projects are being implemented by other agencies and 
international organizations in the project area, and the improved transport from the Project will 
enable  the  full  potential  of  these  other  projects  to  be  realized.  The  Project’s  civil  works  will 
require  approximately  4,400  person-months  of  unskilled  labor.  The  Project  will  encourage 
contractors to hire poor residents of the project area to fill these unskilled labor positions. 
 
50. 
The  poverty  impact  ratio  has  been  calculated  to  illustrate  the  poverty  impact  of  the 
Project. The proportion of benefits accruing to the poor has been estimated for all the benefits 
allocated  by  the  distribution  analysis.  Benefits  to  freight  and  passenger  transport  users  have 
been allocated according to the proportion of transport users that are poor. Users of passenger 
transport services will primarily be residents of the project area, and benefits are allocated using 
the poverty incidence of 91% in the project area. Some freight transport users will be residents 
of  Dushanbe,  which  has  a  lower  poverty  incidence.  Therefore,  an  estimated  83%  (national 
poverty  incidence)  of  road  freight  users  will  be  poor.  It  is  assumed  that  only  5%  of  vehicle 
owners are poor and benefits to the poor were allocated accordingly. The poverty impact ratio is 
estimated  to  be  0.71,  meaning  that  71%  of  the  Project's  benefits  will  accrue  to  the  poor.  The 
Project  is  classified  as  a  poverty  intervention  based  on  the  proportion  of  poor  among  the 
beneficiaries, the proportion of benefits accruing to the poor, and the positive impact it will have 
on other poverty-alleviation projects in the project area.

3. 
As a result of policy dialogue with and technical assistance from ADB, the administration 
of  the  transport  sector  was  reorganized  and  Ministry  of  Transport  (MOT)  was  created.  MOT, 
which  now  includes  Tajik  Rail  (Tajikistan  Railway)  and  Tajik  Air  (Tajikistan  Airlines),  is 
responsible for planning and coordinating  all modes of transport within the country. The current 
organization  chart  for  MOT  is  shown  in  Supplementary  Appendix  A.  The  Government  is

reorganized MOT reflects a policy of promoting competition, increasing the private sector's role, 
and enabling customers to make informed decisions. In the future most state-owned enterprises 
will play a minor role and will be expected to operate as independent commercial enterprises. 
Separate  deputy  ministers  are  responsible  for  rail  transport  and  air  transport.  These  are

6. 
The state budget allocation for road rehabilitation and maintenance varies from year to 
year  according  to  the  Government's  priorities  and  fiscal  constraints.  Prior  to  2000,  road 
subsector expenditures were financed from the Road Fund, the state budget, and development 
agencies. The Road Fund had four main sources: (i) road-user taxes, such as excise taxes on 
purchases  of  vehicles  and  parts,  tires,  fuel,  and  lubricants,  but  including  a  2.5%  tax  on 
transactions  by  all  companies;  (ii)  charges  on  international  transit  shipments;  (iii)  vehicle 
inspection fees and registration fees; and (iv) contributions from local governments. In practice, 
only half of the Road Fund collection was allocated to road rehabilitation and maintenance; the 
other  half  was  used  to  fund  new  construction.  As  a  result  of  general  fiscal  constraints  and 
allocations to new construction, expenditures on road maintenance and rehabilitation have been 
much lower than what was needed to maintain the road network at an acceptable level. Details 
on the current status of road subsector financing are discussed in para. 6 of the main text.

7. 
Maintenance  of  the  road  network  throughout  Tajikistan  virtually  ceased  following  the 
collapse  of  the  Soviet  Union.  Maintenance  funding  was  also  unavailable  during  the  civil  war 
when  numerous  bridges  and  road  sections  were  damaged.  Heavily  loaded  trucks  and  army 
tanks reportedly used the roads during this period and undoubtedly contributed to the structural 
damage  of  the  pavement.  Funding  for  road  maintenance  has  decreased by almost 99% since 
independence, and this inadequate funding is reflected in the deteriorated condition of the road 
network.  Allocation  of  funding  is  often  restricted  to  emergency  maintenance  needs  and  is 
insufficient  for  routine  or  periodic  maintenance  requirements.  Little,  if  any,  preventative 
maintenance activities are currently being undertaken outside of Dushanbe as part of a detailed, 
planned,  and  scheduled  road  maintenance  program.  Following  the  breakup  of  the  state  and 
collective farms, respons ibility for maintenance of the rural and farm roads formerly under their 
jurisdiction now rests with the local district administrations.

1. 

Description of the Project Impact Area 

 
3. 
The primary impact area is largely agricultural. However, there is very little arable land 
per  capita  in  this  part  of  Tajikistan.  The  median  per  capita  holding  of  cropland  in  the  primary 
impact area is only 2/100th of a hectare — only one third the amount of land per person in poor 
areas of eastern and central People's Republic of China,1 for example. Much of the agricultural 
land  is  in  hillside  fields  of  marginal  land  with  slopes  of  up  to  60%  and  subject  to  significant 
erosion.  The  farther  from  Dushanbe,  the  higher  the  elevation,  and  the  lower  the  quality  of  the 
land. Much of the land has been used for subsistence crops since the outbreak of the civil war in 
the 1990s, rather than for cash crops or raising animals. Principal  household crops are wheat, 
potatoes, apples, carrots, onions, and grapes. Livestock is also raised. Much of the best land in 
the  two  Vahdat  (Kofarnikhon)  jamoats  is  used  to  grow  cotton;  however,  much  of  the  income 
goes  to  taxes.  Generally,  for  grain  in  this  area,  the  higher  the  elevation  and  the  steeper  the 
slopes, the lower the quality of the soil and yield per hectare. It would take (on average) 2.35 of 
the land area in Faisabod to produce as much grain as is produced in Vahdat, and 3.33 times 
the area to grow that same amount in Rogun. 
 

2. 

Employment in the Project Area 

 
4. 
Unemployment and underemployment are widespread in the primary impact area. Eight 
of 13 jamoat heads surveyed said that most of the male working age population in their jamoat 
had no job at  all. Two others said that about 50% had no job. Lack of processing capability and 
lack  of  ready  markets  feed  the  continuation  of  low  value  subsistence  agriculture,  thus  limiting 
employment opportunities. All three primary impact districts produce apples, some of which are 
high-value varieties. However, there are no facilities for export to international markets, and no 
facilities  for  processing  the  apples  into  higher  value  foods.  Similarly,  the  uplands  of  the  three 
districts appear to be ideal countryside for dairy farming (the highland areas may be more suited 
to  sheep  and  goats)  for  processing  and  sale  of  products  into  regional  markets.  The civil war 
destroyed  most  of  the  livestock,  which  in  general  has  not  been  replaced  yet.  Electricity; 
communications;  investment  capital  (for  both  plants  and  livestock);  and  cost  effective, 
appropriate,  and  reliable  transport  are  needed  for  development  in  this  area.  Households 
continue to raise wheat to make bread in the mountainous areas where yields are low. Ideally, 
this part of Tajikistan should be raising more high-value, labor-intensive crops for market (and 
processing) while importing wheat produced more efficiently elsewhere.

4. 

Gender Issues 

 
8. 
Well-defined,  traditional  gender  roles  embedded  in  Tajik  culture  are  in  place  in  the 
primary  impact  area  and  largely  observed  by  both  men  and  women.  These  roles  prescribe, 
among other practices, dress and the division of labor within households. This traditional culture 
exists  within  the  context  of  70  years  of  Soviet  official  insistence  upon  equal  opportunity  for 
women.  Neither  observation,  discussion  with  school  heads,  nor  the  survey  data  indicated 
discrimination  against  girls  at  school  or  inequality  of  educational  opportunity.  A  number  of 
women  hold  high  positions  in  local  government.  Women  have,  however,  been  adversely 
affected by the lack of personal security, economic impoverishment, and declining participation, 
as a result of  both  war  and  economic  transition.  Due  to  the  civil  war,  the  number  of  families 
headed  by  single  women  has  increased.  The  economic  transition  has  severely  affected 
industries that  employ  a  high  proportion  of  women  (textiles,  manufacturing,  and  agriculture), 
causing them to be among the first to lose their jobs. Other sectors where women predominate, 
such as health and education, are those where wages are least likely to have been paid. The 
collapse of the state social safety net has exacerbated the number of women and families living 
in  poverty,  while  the  loss  of  quotas  guaranteeing  equal  representation  in  political  and 
governmental bodies has increasingly kept them out of decision-making positions.

1. 

Distribution of Project Benefits 

 
The economic analysis quantified five categories of project benefits: (i) VOC savings for 
12. 
normal traffic, (ii) international generated traffic, (iii) local generated traffic, (iv) poverty reduction 
benefits, and (v) time savings. The project benefits have been distributed among the following 
groups:  (i)  users  of  freight  transport,  (ii)  users  of  passenger  transport,  (iii)  vehicle  owners,  (iv) 
labor, (v) the Government, and (vi) the economy of Tajikistan (Appendix 12). For VOCs, 80% of 
the  savings  are  attributable  to  trucks  and  20%  to  buses  and  cars.  As  the  trucking  industry  in 
Tajikistan  is  in  the  private  sector,  and  competition  is  strong  on  the  project  road,  most  of  the 
reduction in VOCs are likely to be passed on to users in terms of lower transport charges. It is 
assumed that 10% of VOC savings for trucks will go to owners of vehicles and labor; with the 
remaining  90%  to  users.  The  same  percentage  distribution  is  assumed  for  VOC  savings  to 
passenger  vehicles.  These  allocations  of  benefits  have  been  applied  to  benefits  from  normal 
and local generated traffic. Benefits from international generated traffic result from increases in 
trade  and  have  been  allocated  to  the  economy.  Poverty  benefits  represent  real  increases  in 
incomes of poor people in the vicinity of project road, and have been attributed to the economy.

SUMMARY INITIAL ENVIRONMENTAL EXAMINATION 

I. 

INTRODUCTION 

 
This summary initial environmental examination (SIEE) report has been prepared 
1. 
to  evaluate  the  potential  effects  of  the  proposed  Dushanbe-Kyrgyz  Border  Road 
Rehabilitation  Project.  An  initial  environmental  examination  (IEE)  was  prepared  under 
the  project  preparatory  technical  assistance1  in  accordance  with  the  Environmental 
Assessment  Requirements  and  Environmental  Guidelines  for  Selected  Infrastructure 
Development  Projects  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB).  This  SIEE  incorporates 
findings from the IEE led by the Ministry of Transport (MOT), and the project preparatory 
TA consultants, and has been reviewed by the Ministry of Nature Protection (MNP). 
 
2. 
The  scope  and  objectives  of  the  IEE  were  to  (i)  ensure  that  environmental 
concerns  are  fully  taken  into  account  in  the  consideration  of  alternatives  and  in  the 
design  and  construction  specification  aspects  of  the  Project2,  (ii)  review  all  possible 
environmental  impacts  during  and  after  construction,  including  any  possible  need  for 
land  acquisition  and  compensation/resettlement  arrangements  along  the  proposed 
alignment,  and  (iii)  identify  potential  environmental  issues  to  determine  whether  the 
Project warrants a full environmental impact assessment, pursuant to the requirements 
of ADB. 
 

II. 

DESCRIPTION OF THE PROJECT  

 
The  Project  will  improve  the  Dushanbe-Nurobod  (Darband)  portion  of  the  road 
3. 
from  Dushanbe  northeast  toward  the  border  with  the  Kyrgyz  Republic.  The  Project  will 
improve about 140 kilometers of main highway and approximately 77 kilometers of rural 
roads feeding into the project road. The Project includes consulting services for project 
supervision  and  monitoring,  and  procurement  of  equipment  for  road  maintenance,  and 
an associated advisory TA for capacity building and institutional strengthening. 
 

III. 

DESCRIPTION OF THE ENVIRONMENT  

 
4. 
Tajikistan  is  the  most  southerly  of  the  Central  Asian  republics.  It  is  bordered  to 
the  north  by  the  Kyrgyz  Republic,  in  the  east  by  the  People's  Republic  of  China, 
Afghanistan  to  the  south,  and  Uzbekistan  in  the  west.  Total  area  is  143,000  square 
kilometers,  divided  into  four  regions:  Sughd  in  the  north,  the  Region  of  Republican 
Subordination  (RRS)  in  the  center,  Khatlon  in  the  south,  and  the  mainly  mountainous 
Gorno-Badakshan in the east. The project area is located in the RRS. The population of 
Tajikistan  was  about  6.12  million  in  2000.  Most  people  (74%)  live  in  rural  areas. 
Agriculture  is  the  dominant  economic  activity  and  the  largest  source  of  income  and 
employment.  The  population  has  increased  at  an  average  annual  rate  of  about  1.6% 
since the mid-1990s. 
 
The climate is continental, with cold winters and hot, dry summers, although the 
5. 
relatively southerly latitude has an ameliorating impact, and altitude significantly affects 
local  climate.  The  project  area  is  in  the  dry  climate  belt,  with  annual  average

(m)  above  sea  level  at  Dushanbe  to  over  1,850  m  above  sea  level  near  Obigarm. 
Precipitation  ranges  from  650  millimeters  in  Dushanbe  to  1200  millimeters  in  the 
Obigarm-Tavildara Junction area, which experiences about 1 m of snowfall per year. 
 
6. 
Soils are typically silty gray-brown desert soils of alluvial origin and relatively low 
inherent  fertility.  The  concentration  of  organic  matter  is  low  and  erodibility  is  high. 
Groundwater  levels  are  high.  Water  logging  and  secondary  salinization  are  significant 
environmental  problems,  caused  by  failing  drainage  infrastructure  and  poor  water 
management.  Floods  may  occur  at  any  time  due  to  adverse  weather.  Tajikistan  is 
mountainous, with only 960,000 hectares (ha) of arable land (7% of the total area). The 
amount of arable land per rural household is only 0.9 ha, plus about 3.5 ha of pasture. 
Significant areas of often steeply sloping land have been utilized, resulting in increased 
risk of erosion. 
 
Hydrological features in Tajikistan include glaciers and a network of rivers, lakes, 
7. 
and canals. Natural water quality is good. The quantity of industrial wastewater is small. 
The main water pollution source is domestic sewage in settlements, villages, and cities. 
Tajikistan’s  hydropower  production  is  third  in  the  world  after  the  United  States  and 
Russia.  The  most  intense  development  of  these  resources  has  been  in  the  Vakhsh 
Valley where Tajikistan's highest dam (Nurek) is located.3 Due to the current low level of 
industrialization, there are few air pollution sources and air quality, as expected, is good. 
The  main  source  of  air  pollution  is  transport,  accounting  for  70%  of  the  total  air 
pollutants. The dry climate causes natural air pollution (mist and dust storms) during the 
autumn-summer period. 
 
8. 
Topographic characteristics, climate, and soil diversity define the variety of flora 
and fauna. Tajikistan hosts 5,000 plant species, 81 species of mammals, over 365 bird 
species, and 49 species of reptiles. Two hundred twenty-six plant species are included 
in the Red Book of Tajikistan as sensitive,  or potentially threatened or endangered. The 
Government  has  created  a  number  of  reserves,  national  parks,  biological  research 
stations, and natural monuments. In practice, one specially protected reserve has been 
created  in  each  natural  climate  belt.  There  are  4  reserves,  14  small  reserves,  and  2 
national parks.
